instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
threads.message: Hi ive got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.93v <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is missing , diode reading is 450 on pp5v so guessing no short , i see it comes from <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> but cant find where that comes from, under the thermal cam the smc is getting hot . I did see the smc has <SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO</SIGNAL> but not sure if thats what im looking for . The board has reportedly had a spill but cant see any signs anywhere on the board or casing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>?
Check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10) output voltages, at page 60.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
threads.message:
yes i get 3.3v on  <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V_LDO3V</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> =5v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL> = 12.96V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V DIODE 430
<SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_PVCCPCH</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V DIODE SHORT TO GROUND
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.98V
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P5VS4</SIGNAL> = 0V DIODE <SIGNAL>43PMIC_ALLSYSPGD</SIGNAL> = 0V DIODE SHORT TO GROUND
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3S4</SIGNAL> = 0V DIODE 430
<SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_P1V8</SIGNAL> = 0V DIODE 485
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL> = 12.96V 
<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> = 0V DIODE SHORT TO GROUND
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_VREF</SIGNAL> = 1.24V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
threads.message:
Post exact readings for "DIODE SHORT TO GROUND" above mentioned.

<SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> comes on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
threads.message:
diode short readings 0 ohms on all
<SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> at 2.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
threads.message:
Do you mean to have 0 ohm to ground on all these coils???
I hope you've disconnected power first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
threads.message: sorry  <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P5VS4</SIGNAL>  is 499 in diode mode (measured in the wrong place sorry )  but yes the other 2 are o ohm to ground (without the power supply :-) )

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
threads.message:
Bad CPU, or <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
Lift L7690 one side and see where the short remains.
You can use voltage injection method, to find the culprit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 19.3v no boot
threads.message: just for reference if it helps anyone it was a bad cpu :-(
